title: Free the net?
content:
Net neutrality legislation has been rejected by the...the... that big building is washington, forget the name.

Anyway; the issue is whether all data on the net should be treated equally, or if service providers or telecomunications companies [that provide the phone lines the net uses] should be able to charge [websites, not uusers] for a 'premium' service.

Opponents argue that this will stifle innovation, crush small companies and ruin the level playing field of the net.

What is often overlooked is the fact that the net is already uneven. Approximately 15% of *all* net traffic isn't actually sent from the web server, but instead from a company that stores a large part of the net on its servers. [When there is congestion on the net this company is contacted instead and sends you the page uicker than it would when routed from the companies server. Goggle, CNN and microsoft are all customers] Also web servers already block packages [spam and malign code] and prioritize certain data packets, [such as video feed] that needs to be timely. Equality here could be harmful for everyone.

So, should we have an 'equal' net? Or should the infrastructure providers be able t prioritize?
A proud member of the Spleen Extinction society

[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v410/Gannalev/rcwn.png[/img]

"No one should be here."
-Levellord

title: Re: Free the net?
content:
I thought "Goggle" ran their own multi-continent distributed server system, I'd be surprised if they were using someone else's system.

Besides, this stuff already happens, e.g. websites pay more if they want a faster pipe to the 'net.

title: Re: Free the net?
content:
The other thing the United States Congress doesn't understand is that the internet is not in any way "owned" by the United States.

The US can not regulate what say... the UK does with their bandwidth. The only thing they could do is put "Tiers" on the stuff within the US.

They simply don't understand that they can't do this. Actually they don't understand how the internet works.-----------------------
The end of this post. You may stop reading now.

title: Re: Free the net?
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]The US can not regulate what say... the UK does with their bandwidth. The only thing they could do is put "Tiers" on the stuff within the US.[hr][/quote]
It's not that the US wants to legislate a tiered Internet into being; the ISPs themselves want tiers so they can charge people they have no business charging. Everyone pays their ISP for access: from you and me all the way up to Google everyone on the Internet is paying for it. Now some ISPs want to charge people for simply sending traffic through their networks from the network of their provider.

The controversy in the US is over whether there should be laws against charging a fee for better quality-of-service. These will, of course have no effect in other countries. I'm not even sure if it's an issue outside the US, as the possibility of charging fees for decent service depends on regulations. Anyone living where the laws permit it should be very worried.________________
